plausible_answers.text: Southeast Asia, Taiwan, and by many other overseas Chinese

qas.question: Where is the Fujian dialect spoken?
What happens if you speak Hokkien and its close relative Hakka?
What language is Min Nan distantly related to?

context: <b5_0><b6_0><b8_0>Hokkien<b8_0/><b6_0/><b5_0/> /hɒˈkiɛn/ (traditional Chinese: 福建話; simplified Chinese: 福建话; pinyin: Fújiànhuà; Pe̍h-ōe-jī: Hok-kiàn oē) or Quanzhang (Quanzhou–Zhangzhou / Chinchew–Changchew; BP: Zuánziū–Ziāngziū) is a group of mutually intelligible Min Nan Chinese dialects spoken throughout <a0_0><b12_0>Southeast Asia<a0_0/>, Taiwan, and by many other overseas Chinese<b12_0/>. Hokkien originated from a dialect in <a1_0><b10_0>southern Fujian<b10_0/><a1_0/>. It is closely related to the <a2_0><b7_0><b11_0>Teochew<b11_0/><b7_0/><a2_0/>, though <b13_0>mutual comprehension is difficult<b13_0/>, and is somewhat more distantly related to <a3_0><b14_0>Hainanese<b14_0/><a3_0/>. Besides Hokkien, there are also other <b9_0>Min and Hakka dialects<b9_0/> in <a4_0>Fujian province<a4_0/>, most of which are not mutually intelligible with Hokkien.
